3189.text:
and that what they had was secured to your
mother and to you. There has been no new discovery,

3195.text:
of money, or of any other property; but—"
He felt his wrist held closer, and he stopped.

3202.text:
The expression in the forehead, which had
so particularly attracted his notice, and

3208.text:
which was now immovable, had deepened into
one of pain and horror.

3213.text:
"But he has been—been found. He is alive.
Greatly changed, it is too probable; almost

3220.text:
a wreck, it is possible; though we will hope
the best. Still, alive. Your father has been

3227.text:
taken to the house of an old servant in Paris,
and we are going there: I, to identify him

3233.text:
if I can: you, to restore him to life, love,
duty, rest, comfort."

3240.text:
A shiver ran through her frame, and from it
through his. She said, in a low, distinct,

3247.text:
awe-stricken voice, as if she were saying
it in a dream,

3250.text:
"I am going to see his Ghost! It will be his
Ghost—not him!"

3256.text:
Mr. Lorry quietly chafed the hands that held
his arm. "There, there, there! See now, see

3262.text:
now! The best and the worst are known to you,
now. You are well on your way to the poor

3267.text:
wronged gentleman, and, with a fair sea voyage,
and a fair land journey, you will be soon

3273.text:
at his dear side."
She repeated in the same tone, sunk to a whisper,

3280.text:
"I have been free, I have been happy, yet
his Ghost has never haunted me!"

3286.text:
"Only one thing more," said Mr. Lorry, laying
stress upon it as a wholesome means of enforcing

3292.text:
her attention: "he has been found under another
name; his own, long forgotten or long concealed.

3300.text:
It would be worse than useless now to inquire
which; worse than useless to seek to know

3306.text:
whether he has been for years overlooked,
or always designedly held prisoner. It would

3312.text:
be worse than useless now to make any inquiries,
because it would be dangerous. Better not

3318.text:
to mention the subject, anywhere or in any
way, and to remove him—for a while at all

3323.text:
events—out of France. Even I, safe as an
Englishman, and even Tellson's, important

3330.text:
as they are to French credit, avoid all naming

3336.text:
of writing openly referring to it. This is

3343.text:
entries, and memoranda, are all comprehended

3350.text:
may mean anything. But what is the matter!
She doesn't notice a word! Miss Manette!"

3357.text:
Perfectly still and silent, and not even fallen

3363.text:
utterly insensible; with her eyes open and
fixed upon him, and with that last expression

3370.text:
looking as if it were carved or branded into

3376.text:
arm, that he feared to detach himself lest

3382.text:
loudly for assistance without moving.
A wild-looking woman, whom even in his agitation,

3389.text:
Mr. Lorry observed to be all of a red colour,
and to have red hair, and to be dressed in

3394.text:
some extraordinary tight-fitting fashion,
and to have on her head a most wonderful bonnet

3400.text:
like a Grenadier wooden measure, and good
measure too, or a great Stilton cheese, came

3407.text:
running into the room in advance of the inn
servants, and soon settled the question of

3412.text:
his detachment from the poor young lady, by
laying a brawny hand upon his chest, and sending

3418.text:
him flying back against the nearest wall.
("I really think this must be a man!" was

3424.text:
Mr. Lorry's breathless reflection, simultaneously
with his coming against the wall.)

3429.text:
"Why, look at you all!" bawled this figure,
addressing the inn servants. "Why don't you

3435.text:
go and fetch things, instead of standing there
staring at me? I am not so much to look at,

3442.text:
am I? Why don't you go and fetch things? I'll
let you know, if you don't bring smelling-salts,

3447.text:
cold water, and vinegar, quick, I will."
There was an immediate dispersal for these

3454.text:
restoratives, and she softly laid the patient

3460.text:
and gentleness: calling her "my precious!"
and "my bird!" and spreading her golden hair

3466.text:
aside over her shoulders with great pride
and care.

3470.text:
"And you in brown!" she said, indignantly
turning to Mr. Lorry; "couldn't you tell her

3477.text:
what you had to tell her, without frightening
her to death? Look at her, with her pretty

3482.text:
pale face and her cold hands. Do you call
_that_ being a Banker?"

3490.text:
Mr. Lorry was so exceedingly disconcerted
by a question so hard to answer, that he could

3496.text:
only look on, at a distance, with much feebler
sympathy and humility, while the strong woman,

3503.text:
having banished the inn servants under the
mysterious penalty of "letting them know"

3508.text:
something not mentioned if they stayed there,
staring, recovered her charge by a regular

3514.text:
series of gradations, and coaxed her to lay
her drooping head upon her shoulder.

3519.text:
"I hope she will do well now," said Mr. Lorry.
"No thanks to you in brown, if she does. My

3527.text:
darling pretty!"
"I hope," said Mr. Lorry, after another pause

3532.text:
of feeble sympathy and humility, "that you
accompany Miss Manette to France?"

3537.text:
"A likely thing, too!" replied the strong
woman. "If it was ever intended that I should

3543.text:
go across salt water, do you suppose Providence
would have cast my lot in an island?"

3550.text:
This being another question hard to answer,

3560.text:
Chapter V. The Wine-shop
A large cask of wine had been dropped and

3568.text:
broken, in the street. The accident had happened
in getting it out of a cart; the cask had

3574.text:
tumbled out with a run, the hoops had burst,
and it lay on the stones just outside the

3579.text:
door of the wine-shop, shattered like a walnut-shell.
All the people within reach had suspended

3586.text:
their business, or their idleness, to run
to the spot and drink the wine. The rough,

3591.text:
irregular stones of the street, pointing every
way, and designed, one might have thought,

3596.text:
expressly to lame all living creatures that
approached them, had dammed it into little

3601.text:
pools; these were surrounded, each by its
own jostling group or crowd, according to

3607.text:
its size. Some men kneeled down, made scoops
of their two hands joined, and sipped, or

3614.text:
tried to help women, who bent over their shoulders,
to sip, before the wine had all run out between

3619.text:
their fingers. Others, men and women, dipped
in the puddles with little mugs of mutilated

3625.text:
earthenware, or even with handkerchiefs from
women's heads, which were squeezed dry into

3631.text:
infants' mouths; others made small mud-embankments,
to stem the wine as it ran; others, directed

3639.text:
by lookers-on up at high windows, darted here
and there, to cut off little streams of wine

3645.text:
that started away in new directions; others
devoted themselves to the sodden and lee-dyed

3651.text:
pieces of the cask, licking, and even champing
the moister wine-rotted fragments with eager

3658.text:
relish. There was no drainage to carry off
the wine, and not only did it all get taken

3663.text:
up, but so much mud got taken up along with
it, that there might have been a scavenger

3668.text:
in the street, if anybody acquainted with
it could have believed in such a miraculous

3673.text:
presence.
A shrill sound of laughter and of amused voices—voices

3679.text:
of men, women, and children—resounded in
the street while this wine game lasted. There

3685.text:
was little roughness in the sport, and much
playfulness. There was a special companionship

3691.text:
in it, an observable inclination on the part
of every one to join some other one, which

3697.text:
led, especially among the luckier or lighter-hearted,
to frolicsome embraces, drinking of healths,

3705.text:
shaking of hands, and even joining of hands
and dancing, a dozen together. When the wine

3711.text:
was gone, and the places where it had been
most abundant were raked into a gridiron-pattern

3717.text:
by fingers, these demonstrations ceased, as
suddenly as they had broken out. The man who

3724.text:
had left his saw sticking in the firewood
he was cutting, set it in motion again; the

3730.text:
women who had left on a door-step the little
pot of hot ashes, at which she had been trying

3735.text:
to soften the pain in her own starved fingers
and toes, or in those of her child, returned

3741.text:
to it; men with bare arms, matted locks, and
cadaverous faces, who had emerged into the

3748.text:
winter light from cellars, moved away, to
descend again; and a gloom gathered on the

3755.text:
scene that appeared more natural to it than
sunshine.

3760.text:
The wine was red wine, and had stained the
ground of the narrow street in the suburb

3765.text:
of Saint Antoine, in Paris, where it was spilled.
It had stained many hands, too, and many faces,

3773.text:
and many naked feet, and many wooden shoes.
The hands of the man who sawed the wood, left

3779.text:
red marks on the billets; and the forehead
of the woman who nursed her baby, was stained

3784.text:
with the stain of the old rag she wound about
her head again. Those who had been greedy

3790.text:
with the staves of the cask, had acquired
a tigerish smear about the mouth; and one

3796.text:
tall joker so besmirched, his head more out
of a long squalid bag of a nightcap than in

3803.text:
it, scrawled upon a wall with his finger dipped
in muddy wine-lees—BLOOD.

3808.text:
The time was to come, when that wine too would
be spilled on the street-stones, and when

3816.text:
the stain of it would be red upon many there.
And now that the cloud settled on Saint Antoine,

3825.text:
which a momentary gleam had driven from his
sacred countenance, the darkness of it was

3830.text:
heavy—cold, dirt, sickness, ignorance, and
want, were the lords in waiting on the saintly

3838.text:
presence—nobles of great power all of them;
but, most especially the last. Samples of

3845.text:
a people that had undergone a terrible grinding
and regrinding in the mill, and certainly

3851.text:
not in the fabulous mill which ground old
people young, shivered at every corner, passed

3857.text:
in and out at every doorway, looked from every
window, fluttered in every vestige of a garment

3863.text:
that the wind shook. The mill which had worked
them down, was the mill that grinds young

3871.text:
people old; the children had ancient faces
and grave voices; and upon them, and upon

3879.text:
the grown faces, and ploughed into every furrow
of age and coming up afresh, was the sigh,

3886.text:
Hunger. It was prevalent everywhere. Hunger
was pushed out of the tall houses, in the

3892.text:
wretched clothing that hung upon poles and
lines; Hunger was patched into them with straw

3899.text:
and rag and wood and paper; Hunger was repeated
in every fragment of the small modicum of

3905.text:
firewood that the man sawed off; Hunger stared
down from the smokeless chimneys, and started

3912.text:
up from the filthy street that had no offal,
among its refuse, of anything to eat. Hunger

3919.text:
was the inscription on the baker's shelves,
written in every small loaf of his scanty

3925.text:
stock of bad bread; at the sausage-shop, in
every dead-dog preparation that was offered

3932.text:
for sale. Hunger rattled its dry bones among
the roasting chestnuts in the turned cylinder;

3939.text:
Hunger was shred into atomics in every farthing
porringer of husky chips of potato, fried

3946.text:
with some reluctant drops of oil.
Its abiding place was in all things fitted

3953.text:
to it. A narrow winding street, full of offence
and stench, with other narrow winding streets

3961.text:
diverging, all peopled by rags and nightcaps,
and all smelling of rags and nightcaps, and

3969.text:
all visible things with a brooding look upon
them that looked ill. In the hunted air of

3976.text:
the people there was yet some wild-beast thought
of the possibility of turning at bay. Depressed

3982.text:
and slinking though they were, eyes of fire
were not wanting among them; nor compressed

3989.text:
lips, white with what they suppressed; nor
foreheads knitted into the likeness of the

3995.text:
gallows-rope they mused about enduring, or
inflicting. The trade signs (and they were

4002.text:
almost as many as the shops) were, all, grim
illustrations of Want. The butcher and the

4009.text:
porkman painted up, only the leanest scrags
of meat; the baker, the coarsest of meagre

4016.text:
loaves. The people rudely pictured as drinking
in the wine-shops, croaked over their scanty

4022.text:
measures of thin wine and beer, and were gloweringly
confidential together. Nothing was represented

4030.text:
in a flourishing condition, save tools and
weapons; but, the cutler's knives and axes

4037.text:
were sharp and bright, the smith's hammers
were heavy, and the gunmaker's stock was murderous.

4044.text:
The crippling stones of the pavement, with
their many little reservoirs of mud and water,

4050.text:
had no footways, but broke off abruptly at
the doors. The kennel, to make amends, ran

4056.text:
down the middle of the street—when it ran
at all: which was only after heavy rains,

4061.text:
and then it ran, by many eccentric fits, into
the houses. Across the streets, at wide intervals,

4069.text:
one clumsy lamp was slung by a rope and pulley;
at night, when the lamplighter had let these

4075.text:
down, and lighted, and hoisted them again,
a feeble grove of dim wicks swung in a sickly

4083.text:
manner overhead, as if they were at sea. Indeed
they were at sea, and the ship and crew were

4091.text:
in peril of tempest.
For, the time was to come, when the gaunt

4097.text:
scarecrows of that region should have watched
the lamplighter, in their idleness and hunger,

4103.text:
so long, as to conceive the idea of improving
on his method, and hauling up men by those

4110.text:
ropes and pulleys, to flare upon the darkness
of their condition. But, the time was not

4117.text:
come yet; and every wind that blew over France
shook the rags of the scarecrows in vain,

4123.text:
for the birds, fine of song and feather, took
no warning.

4129.text:
The wine-shop was a corner shop, better than
most others in its appearance and degree,

4135.text:
and the master of the wine-shop had stood
outside it, in a yellow waistcoat and green

4140.text:
breeches, looking on at the struggle for the
lost wine. "It's not my affair," said he,

4146.text:
with a final shrug of the shoulders. "The
people from the market did it. Let them bring

4150.text:
another."
There, his eyes happening to catch the tall

4154.text:
joker writing up his joke, he called to him
across the way:

4159.text:
"Say, then, my Gaspard, what do you do there?"
The fellow pointed to his joke with immense

4165.text:
significance, as is often the way with his
tribe. It missed its mark, and completely

4171.text:
failed, as is often the way with his tribe
too.

4174.text:
"What now? Are you a subject for the mad hospital?"
said the wine-shop keeper, crossing the road,

4181.text:
and obliterating the jest with a handful of
mud, picked up for the purpose, and smeared

4186.text:
over it. "Why do you write in the public streets?
Is there—tell me thou—is there no other

4192.text:
place to write such words in?"
In his expostulation he dropped his cleaner

4198.text:
hand (perhaps accidentally, perhaps not) upon
the joker's heart. The joker rapped it with

4204.text:
his own, took a nimble spring upward, and
came down in a fantastic dancing attitude,

4211.text:
with one of his stained shoes jerked off his
foot into his hand, and held out. A joker

4217.text:
of an extremely, not to say wolfishly practical
character, he looked, under those circumstances.

4223.text:
"Put it on, put it on," said the other. "Call
wine, wine; and finish there." With that advice,

4231.text:
he wiped his soiled hand upon the joker's
dress, such as it was—quite deliberately,

4237.text:
as having dirtied the hand on his account;
and then recrossed the road and entered the

4242.text:
wine-shop.
This wine-shop keeper was a bull-necked, martial-looking

4247.text:
man of thirty, and he should have been of
a hot temperament, for, although it was a

4252.text:
bitter day, he wore no coat, but carried one
slung over his shoulder. His shirt-sleeves

4257.text:
were rolled up, too, and his brown arms were
bare to the elbows. Neither did he wear anything

4263.text:
more on his head than his own crisply-curling
short dark hair. He was a dark man altogether,

4271.text:
with good eyes and a good bold breadth between
them. Good-humoured looking on the whole,

4277.text:
but implacable-looking, too; evidently a man
of a strong resolution and a set purpose;

4283.text:
a man not desirable to be met, rushing down
a narrow pass with a gulf on either side,

4288.text:
for nothing would turn the man.
Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop

4295.text:
behind the counter as he came in. Madame Defarge
was a stout woman of about his own age, with

4302.text:
a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look
at anything, a large hand heavily ringed,

4307.text:
a steady face, strong features, and great
composure of manner. There was a character

4313.text:
about Madame Defarge, from which one might
have predicated that she did not often make

4319.text:
mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings
over which she presided. Madame Defarge being

4326.text:
sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and
had a quantity of bright shawl twined about

4333.text:
her head, though not to the concealment of
her large earrings. Her knitting was before

4338.text:
her, but she had laid it down to pick her
teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with

4344.text:
her right elbow supported by her left hand,
Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord

4350.text:
came in, but coughed just one grain of cough.
This, in combination with the lifting of her

4357.text:
darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick
by the breadth of a line, suggested to her

4363.text:
husband that he would do well to look round
the shop among the customers, for any new

4367.text:
customer who had dropped in while he stepped
over the way.

4373.text:
The wine-shop keeper accordingly rolled his
eyes about, until they rested upon an elderly

4378.text:
gentleman and a young lady, who were seated
in a corner. Other company were there: two

4384.text:
playing cards, two playing dominoes, three
standing by the counter lengthening out a

4390.text:
short supply of wine. As he passed behind
the counter, he took notice that the elderly

4396.text:
gentleman said in a look to the young lady,
"This is our man."

4400.text:
"What the devil do _you_ do in that galley
there?" said Monsieur Defarge to himself;

4405.text:
"I don't know you."
But, he feigned not to notice the two strangers,

4410.text:
and fell into discourse with the triumvirate
of customers who were drinking at the counter.

4415.text:
"How goes it, Jacques?" said one of these
three to Monsieur Defarge. "Is all the spilt

4421.text:
wine swallowed?"
"Every drop, Jacques," answered Monsieur Defarge.

4426.text:
When this interchange of Christian name was
effected, Madame Defarge, picking her teeth

4432.text:
with her toothpick, coughed another grain
of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth

4438.text:
of another line.
"It is not often," said the second of the

4442.text:
three, addressing Monsieur Defarge, "that
many of these miserable beasts know the taste

4448.text:
of wine, or of anything but black bread and
death. Is it not so, Jacques?"

4454.text:
"It is so, Jacques," Monsieur Defarge returned.
At this second interchange of the Christian

4461.text:
name, Madame Defarge, still using her toothpick
with profound composure, coughed another grain

4468.text:
of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth
of another line.

4473.text:
The last of the three now said his say, as
he put down his empty drinking vessel and

4479.text:
smacked his lips.
"Ah! So much the worse! A bitter taste it

4484.text:
is that such poor cattle always have in their
mouths, and hard lives they live, Jacques.

4489.text:
Am I right, Jacques?"
"You are right, Jacques," was the response

4493.text:
of Monsieur Defarge.
This third interchange of the Christian name

4498.text:
was completed at the moment when Madame Defarge
put her toothpick by, kept her eyebrows up,

4505.text:
and slightly rustled in her seat.
"Hold then! True!" muttered her husband. "Gentlemen—my

4513.text:
wife!"
The three customers pulled off their hats

4516.text:
to Madame Defarge, with three flourishes.
She acknowledged their homage by bending her

4522.text:
head, and giving them a quick look. Then she
glanced in a casual manner round the wine-shop,

4528.text:
took up her knitting with great apparent calmness
and repose of spirit, and became absorbed

4534.text:
in it.
"Gentlemen," said her husband, who had kept

4537.text:
his bright eye observantly upon her, "good
day. The chamber, furnished bachelor-fashion,

4544.text:
that you wished to see, and were inquiring
for when I stepped out, is on the fifth floor.

4550.text:
The doorway of the staircase gives on the
little courtyard close to the left here,"

4555.text:
pointing with his hand, "near to the window
of my establishment. But, now that I remember,

4561.text:
one of you has already been there, and can
show the way. Gentlemen, adieu!"

4566.text:
They paid for their wine, and left the place.
The eyes of Monsieur Defarge were studying

4572.text:
his wife at her knitting when the elderly
gentleman advanced from his corner, and begged

4578.text:
the favour of a word.
"Willingly, sir," said Monsieur Defarge, and

4583.text:
quietly stepped with him to the door.
Their conference was very short, but very

4588.text:
decided. Almost at the first word, Monsieur
Defarge started and became deeply attentive.

4595.text:
It had not lasted a minute, when he nodded
and went out. The gentleman then beckoned

4600.text:
to the young lady, and they, too, went out.
Madame Defarge knitted with nimble fingers

4606.text:
and steady eyebrows, and saw nothing.
Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette, emerging

4614.text:
from the wine-shop thus, joined Monsieur Defarge
in the doorway to which he had directed his

4620.text:
own company just before. It opened from a
stinking little black courtyard, and was the

4626.text:
general public entrance to a great pile of
houses, inhabited by a great number of people.

4632.text:
In the gloomy tile-paved entry to the gloomy
tile-paved staircase, Monsieur Defarge bent

4639.text:
down on one knee to the child of his old master,
and put her hand to his lips. It was a gentle

4645.text:
action, but not at all gently done; a very
remarkable transformation had come over him

4651.text:
in a few seconds. He had no good-humour in
his face, nor any openness of aspect left,

4658.text:
but had become a secret, angry, dangerous
man.

4662.text:
"It is very high; it is a little difficult.
Better to begin slowly." Thus, Monsieur Defarge,

4669.text:
in a stern voice, to Mr. Lorry, as they began
ascending the stairs.

4675.text:
"Is he alone?" the latter whispered.
"Alone! God help him, who should be with him!"

4682.text:
said the other, in the same low voice.
"Is he always alone, then?"

4690.text:
"Of his own necessity. As he was, when I first
saw him after they found me and demanded to

4696.text:
know if I would take him, and, at my peril
be discreet—as he was then, so he is now."

4709.text:
The keeper of the wine-shop stopped to strike
the wall with his hand, and mutter a tremendous

4715.text:
curse. No direct answer could have been half
so forcible. Mr. Lorry's spirits grew heavier

4722.text:
and heavier, as he and his two companions
ascended higher and higher.

4727.text:
Such a staircase, with its accessories, in
the older and more crowded parts of Paris,

4734.text:
would be bad enough now; but, at that time,
it was vile indeed to unaccustomed and unhardened

4742.text:
senses. Every little habitation within the
great foul nest of one high building—that

4748.text:
is to say, the room or rooms within every
door that opened on the general staircase—left

4754.text:
its own heap of refuse on its own landing,
besides flinging other refuse from its own

4760.text:
windows. The uncontrollable and hopeless mass
of decomposition so engendered, would have

4766.text:
polluted the air, even if poverty and deprivation
had not loaded it with their intangible impurities;

4774.text:
the two bad sources combined made it almost
insupportable. Through such an atmosphere,

4782.text:
by a steep dark shaft of dirt and poison,
the way lay. Yielding to his own disturbance

4789.text:
of mind, and to his young companion's agitation,
which became greater every instant, Mr. Jarvis

4797.text:
Lorry twice stopped to rest. Each of these
stoppages was made at a doleful grating, by

4803.text:
which any languishing good airs that were

spoilt and sickly vapours seemed to crawl
in. Through the rusted bars, tastes, rather

4817.text:
than glimpses, were caught of the jumbled

4822.text:
or lower than the summits of the two great

4828.text:
of healthy life or wholesome aspirations.

4836.text:
and they stopped for the third time. There
was yet an upper staircase, of a steeper inclination

4843.text:
and of contracted dimensions, to be ascended,
before the garret story was reached. The keeper

4850.text:
of the wine-shop, always going a little in

4855.text:
Mr. Lorry took, as though he dreaded to be
asked any question by the young lady, turned

4861.text:
himself about here, and, carefully feeling

4866.text:
his shoulder, took out a key.

4872.text:
Mr. Lorry, surprised.
"Ay. Yes," was the grim reply of Monsieur

4876.text:
Defarge.
"You think it necessary to keep the unfortunate

4880.text:
gentleman so retired?"
"I think it necessary to turn the key." Monsieur

4886.text:
Defarge whispered it closer in his ear, and

4891.text:
"Why?"
"Why! Because he has lived so long, locked

4895.text:
up, that he would be frightened—rave—tear

4901.text:
what harm—if his door was left open."
"Is it possible!" exclaimed Mr. Lorry.

4908.text:
"Is it possible!" repeated Defarge, bitterly.
"Yes. And a beautiful world we live in, when

4915.text:
it _is_ possible, and when many other such

4921.text:
but done—done, see you!—under that sky

4927.text:
us go on."

4933.text:

4938.text:
trembled under such strong emotion, and her

4945.text:

4951.text:
two of reassurance.
"Courage, dear miss! Courage! Business! The

4956.text:
worst will be over in a moment; it is but
passing the room-door, and the worst is over.

4962.text:
Then, all the good you bring to him, all the

4967.text:
begin. Let our good friend here, assist you

4973.text:
Come, now. Business, business!"
They went up slowly and softly. The staircase

4979.text:
was short, and they were soon at the top.
There, as it had an abrupt turn in it, they

4985.text:
came all at once in sight of three men, whose

4990.text:
side of a door, and who were intently looking

4995.text:
through some chinks or holes in the wall.
On hearing footsteps close at hand, these

5001.text:
three turned, and rose, and showed themselves

5007.text:
in the wine-shop.

5012.text:
explained Monsieur Defarge. "Leave us, good
boys; we have business here."

5016.text:
The three glided by, and went silently down.
There appearing to be no other door on that

5022.text:
floor, and the keeper of the wine-shop going

5028.text:
Mr. Lorry asked him in a whisper, with a little

5031.text:
"Do you make a show of Monsieur Manette?"
"I show him, in the way you have seen, to

5039.text:
"_I_ think it is well."

5043.text:
"I choose them as real men, of my name—Jacques
is my name—to whom the sight is likely to

5050.text:
do good. Enough; you are English; that is
another thing. Stay there, if you please,

5055.text:
a little moment."
With an admonitory gesture to keep them back,

5060.text:
he stooped, and looked in through the crevice

5066.text:
he struck twice or thrice upon the door—evidently

5072.text:
there. With the same intention, he drew the
key across it, three or four times, before

5078.text:
he put it clumsily into the lock, and turned
it as heavily as he could.

5084.text:
The door slowly opened inward under his hand,
and he looked into the room and said something.

5090.text:
A faint voice answered something. Little more
than a single syllable could have been spoken

5097.text:
on either side.
He looked back over his shoulder, and beckoned

5101.text:
them to enter. Mr. Lorry got his arm securely
round the daughter's waist, and held her;

5107.text:
for he felt that she was sinking.
"A-a-a-business, business!" he urged, with

5113.text:
a moisture that was not of business shining
on his cheek. "Come in, come in!"

5118.text:
"I am afraid of it," she answered, shuddering.
"Of it? What?"

5122.text:
"I mean of him. Of my father."
Rendered in a manner desperate, by her state

5129.text:
and by the beckoning of their conductor, he
drew over his neck the arm that shook upon

5134.text:
his shoulder, lifted her a little, and hurried
her into the room. He sat her down just within

5140.text:
the door, and held her, clinging to him.
Defarge drew out the key, closed the door,

5148.text:
locked it on the inside, took out the key
again, and held it in his hand. All this he

5153.text:
did, methodically, and with as loud and harsh
an accompaniment of noise as he could make.

5159.text:
Finally, he walked across the room with a
measured tread to where the window was. He

5165.text:
stopped there, and faced round.
The garret, built to be a depository for firewood

5172.text:
and the like, was dim and dark: for, the window
of dormer shape, was in truth a door in the

5178.text:
roof, with a little crane over it for the
hoisting up of stores from the street: unglazed,

5184.text:
and closing up the middle in two pieces, like
any other door of French construction. To

5190.text:
exclude the cold, one half of this door was
fast closed, and the other was opened but

5195.text:
a very little way. Such a scanty portion of
light was admitted through these means, that

5201.text:
it was difficult, on first coming in, to see
anything; and long habit alone could have

5207.text:
slowly formed in any one, the ability to do
any work requiring nicety in such obscurity.

5214.text:
Yet, work of that kind was being done in the
garret; for, with his back towards the door,

5220.text:
and his face towards the window where the
keeper of the wine-shop stood looking at him,

5225.text:
a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping
forward and very busy, making shoes.

5240.text:
Chapter VI. The Shoemaker
"Good day!" said Monsieur Defarge, looking

5246.text:
down at the white head that bent low over
the shoemaking.

5250.text:
It was raised for a moment, and a very faint
voice responded to the salutation, as if it

5258.text:
"You are still hard at work, I see?"
After a long silence, the head was lifted

5264.text:
for another moment, and the voice replied,
"Yes—I am working." This time, a pair of

5270.text:
haggard eyes had looked at the questioner,
before the face had dropped again.

5276.text:
The faintness of the voice was pitiable and
dreadful. It was not the faintness of physical

5282.text:
weakness, though confinement and hard fare
no doubt had their part in it. Its deplorable

5289.text:
peculiarity was, that it was the faintness
of solitude and disuse. It was like the last

5296.text:
feeble echo of a sound made long and long
ago. So entirely had it lost the life and

5304.text:
resonance of the human voice, that it affected
the senses like a once beautiful colour faded

5310.text:
away into a poor weak stain. So sunken and
suppressed it was, that it was like a voice

5317.text:
underground. So expressive it was, of a hopeless
and lost creature, that a famished traveller,

5325.text:
wearied out by lonely wandering in a wilderness,
would have remembered home and friends in

5330.text:
such a tone before lying down to die.
Some minutes of silent work had passed: and

5337.text:
the haggard eyes had looked up again: not
with any interest or curiosity, but with a

5343.text:
dull mechanical perception, beforehand, that
the spot where the only visitor they were

5348.text:
aware of had stood, was not yet empty.
"I want," said Defarge, who had not removed

5356.text:
his gaze from the shoemaker, "to let in a
little more light here. You can bear a little

5361.text:
more?"
The shoemaker stopped his work; looked with

5365.text:
a vacant air of listening, at the floor on
one side of him; then similarly, at the floor

5370.text:
on the other side of him; then, upward at
the speaker.

5374.text:
"What did you say?"
"You can bear a little more light?"

5379.text:
"I must bear it, if you let it in." (Laying
the palest shadow of a stress upon the second

5388.text:
word.)
The opened half-door was opened a little further,

5392.text:
and secured at that angle for the time. A
broad ray of light fell into the garret, and

5398.text:
showed the workman with an unfinished shoe
upon his lap, pausing in his labour. His few

5404.text:
common tools and various scraps of leather
were at his feet and on his bench. He had

5410.text:
a white beard, raggedly cut, but not very
long, a hollow face, and exceedingly bright

5416.text:
eyes. The hollowness and thinness of his face
would have caused them to look large, under

5422.text:
his yet dark eyebrows and his confused white
hair, though they had been really otherwise;

5428.text:
but, they were naturally large, and looked
unnaturally so. His yellow rags of shirt lay

5436.text:
open at the throat, and showed his body to
be withered and worn. He, and his old canvas

5443.text:
frock, and his loose stockings, and all his
poor tatters of clothes, had, in a long seclusion

5450.text:
from direct light and air, faded down to such
a dull uniformity of parchment-yellow, that

5456.text:
it would have been hard to say which was which.
He had put up a hand between his eyes and

5463.text:
the light, and the very bones of it seemed
transparent. So he sat, with a steadfastly

5470.text:
vacant gaze, pausing in his work. He never
looked at the figure before him, without first

5476.text:
looking down on this side of himself, then
on that, as if he had lost the habit of associating

5482.text:
place with sound; he never spoke, without
first wandering in this manner, and forgetting

5488.text:
to speak.
"Are you going to finish that pair of shoes

5492.text:
to-day?" asked Defarge, motioning to Mr. Lorry
to come forward.

5497.text:
"What did you say?"
"Do you mean to finish that pair of shoes

5501.text:
to-day?"
"I can't say that I mean to. I suppose so.

5506.text:
I don't know."
But, the question reminded him of his work,

5511.text:
and he bent over it again.
Mr. Lorry came silently forward, leaving the

5517.text:
daughter by the door. When he had stood, for
a minute or two, by the side of Defarge, the

5524.text:
shoemaker looked up. He showed no surprise
at seeing another figure, but the unsteady

5530.text:
fingers of one of his hands strayed to his
lips as he looked at it (his lips and his

5536.text:
nails were of the same pale lead-colour),
and then the hand dropped to his work, and

5541.text:
he once more bent over the shoe. The look
and the action had occupied but an instant.

5547.text:
"You have a visitor, you see," said Monsieur
Defarge.

5551.text:
"What did you say?"
"Here is a visitor."

5556.text:
The shoemaker looked up as before, but without
removing a hand from his work.

5561.text:
"Come!" said Defarge. "Here is monsieur, who
knows a well-made shoe when he sees one. Show

5567.text:
him that shoe you are working at. Take it,
monsieur."

5571.text:
Mr. Lorry took it in his hand.
"Tell monsieur what kind of shoe it is, and

5576.text:
the maker's name."
There was a longer pause than usual, before

5582.text:
the shoemaker replied:
"I forget what it was you asked me. What did

5588.text:
you say?"
"I said, couldn't you describe the kind of

5592.text:
shoe, for monsieur's information?"
"It is a lady's shoe. It is a young lady's

5599.text:
walking-shoe. It is in the present mode. I
never saw the mode. I have had a pattern in

5605.text:
my hand." He glanced at the shoe with some
little passing touch of pride.

5611.text:
"And the maker's name?" said Defarge.
Now that he had no work to hold, he laid the

5619.text:
knuckles of the right hand in the hollow of
the left, and then the knuckles of the left

5623.text:
hand in the hollow of the right, and then
passed a hand across his bearded chin, and

5629.text:
so on in regular changes, without a moment's
intermission. The task of recalling him from

5635.text:
the vagrancy into which he always sank when
he had spoken, was like recalling some very

5640.text:
weak person from a swoon, or endeavouring,
in the hope of some disclosure, to stay the

5646.text:
spirit of a fast-dying man.
"Did you ask me for my name?"

5654.text:
"Assuredly I did."
"One Hundred and Five, North Tower."

5660.text:
"Is that all?"
"One Hundred and Five, North Tower."

5667.text:
With a weary sound that was not a sigh, nor
a groan, he bent to work again, until the

5674.text:
silence was again broken.
"You are not a shoemaker by trade?" said Mr.

5680.text:
Lorry, looking steadfastly at him.
His haggard eyes turned to Defarge as if he

5687.text:
would have transferred the question to him:
but as no help came from that quarter, they

5692.text:
turned back on the questioner when they had
sought the ground.

5696.text:
"I am not a shoemaker by trade? No, I was
not a shoemaker by trade. I-I learnt it here.

5705.text:
I taught myself. I asked leave to—"
He lapsed away, even for minutes, ringing

5714.text:
those measured changes on his hands the whole
time. His eyes came slowly back, at last,

5720.text:
to the face from which they had wandered;
when they rested on it, he started, and resumed,

5726.text:
in the manner of a sleeper that moment awake,
reverting to a subject of last night.

5732.text:
"I asked leave to teach myself, and I got
it with much difficulty after a long while,

5739.text:
and I have made shoes ever since."
As he held out his hand for the shoe that

5746.text:
had been taken from him, Mr. Lorry said, still
looking steadfastly in his face:

5753.text:
"Monsieur Manette, do you remember nothing
of me?"

5757.text:
The shoe dropped to the ground, and he sat
looking fixedly at the questioner.

5762.text:
"Monsieur Manette"; Mr. Lorry laid his hand
upon Defarge's arm; "do you remember nothing

5768.text:
of this man? Look at him. Look at me. Is there
no old banker, no old business, no old servant,

5776.text:
no old time, rising in your mind, Monsieur
Manette?"

5782.text:
As the captive of many years sat looking fixedly,
by turns, at Mr. Lorry and at Defarge, some

5789.text:
long obliterated marks of an actively intent
intelligence in the middle of the forehead,

5796.text:
gradually forced themselves through the black
mist that had fallen on him. They were overclouded

5803.text:
again, they were fainter, they were gone;
but they had been there. And so exactly was

5810.text:
the expression repeated on the fair young
face of her who had crept along the wall to

5816.text:
a point where she could see him, and where
she now stood looking at him, with hands which

5822.text:
at first had been only raised in frightened
compassion, if not even to keep him off and

5827.text:
shut out the sight of him, but which were
now extending towards him, trembling with

5832.text:
eagerness to lay the spectral face upon her
warm young breast, and love it back to life

5838.text:
and hope—so exactly was the expression repeated
(though in stronger characters) on her fair

5845.text:
young face, that it looked as though it had
passed like a moving light, from him to her.

5852.text:
Darkness had fallen on him in its place. He
looked at the two, less and less attentively,

5858.text:
and his eyes in gloomy abstraction sought
the ground and looked about him in the old

5864.text:
way. Finally, with a deep long sigh, he took
the shoe up, and resumed his work.

5872.text:
"Have you recognised him, monsieur?" asked
Defarge in a whisper.

5878.text:
"Yes; for a moment. At first I thought it
quite hopeless, but I have unquestionably

5884.text:
seen, for a single moment, the face that I
once knew so well. Hush! Let us draw further

5891.text:
back. Hush!"
She had moved from the wall of the garret,

5894.text:
very near to the bench on which he sat. There
was something awful in his unconsciousness

5901.text:
of the figure that could have put out its
hand and touched him as he stooped over his

5906.text:
labour.
Not a word was spoken, not a sound was made.

5911.text:
She stood, like a spirit, beside him, and
he bent over his work.

5916.text:
It happened, at length, that he had occasion
to change the instrument in his hand, for

5922.text:
his shoemaker's knife. It lay on that side
of him which was not the side on which she

5928.text:
stood. He had taken it up, and was stooping
to work again, when his eyes caught the skirt

5935.text:
of her dress. He raised them, and saw her
face. The two spectators started forward,

5941.text:
but she stayed them with a motion of her hand.
She had no fear of his striking at her with

5947.text:
the knife, though they had.
He stared at her with a fearful look, and

5953.text:
after a while his lips began to form some
words, though no sound proceeded from them.

5960.text:
By degrees, in the pauses of his quick and
laboured breathing, he was heard to say:

5966.text:
"What is this?"
With the tears streaming down her face, she

5973.text:
put her two hands to her lips, and kissed
them to him; then clasped them on her breast,

5978.text:
as if she laid his ruined head there.
"You are not the gaoler's daughter?"

5994.text:
Not yet trusting the tones of her voice, she
sat down on the bench beside him. He recoiled,

6002.text:
but she laid her hand upon his arm. A strange
thrill struck him when she did so, and visibly

6008.text:
passed over his frame; he laid the knife down
softly, as he sat staring at her.

6014.text:
Her golden hair, which she wore in long curls,
had been hurriedly pushed aside, and fell

6021.text:
down over her neck. Advancing his hand by
little and little, he took it up and looked

6027.text:
at it. In the midst of the action he went
astray, and, with another deep sigh, fell

6032.text:
to work at his shoemaking.
But not for long. Releasing his arm, she laid

6037.text:
her hand upon his shoulder. After looking
doubtfully at it, two or three times, as if

6043.text:
to be sure that it was really there, he laid
down his work, put his hand to his neck, and

6049.text:
took off a blackened string with a scrap of
folded rag attached to it. He opened this,

6056.text:
carefully, on his knee, and it contained a
very little quantity of hair: not more than

6061.text:
one or two long golden hairs, which he had,
in some old day, wound off upon his finger.

6068.text:
He took her hair into his hand again, and
looked closely at it. "It is the same. How

6074.text:
can it be! When was it! How was it!"
As the concentrated expression returned to

6081.text:
his forehead, he seemed to become conscious
that it was in hers too. He turned her full

6087.text:
to the light, and looked at her.
"She had laid her head upon my shoulder, that

6093.text:
night when I was summoned out—she had a
fear of my going, though I had none—and

6098.text:
when I was brought to the North Tower they
found these upon my sleeve. 'You will leave

6105.text:
me them? They can never help me to escape
in the body, though they may in the spirit.'

6111.text:
Those were the words I said. I remember them
very well."

6117.text:
He formed this speech with his lips many times
before he could utter it. But when he did

6123.text:
find spoken words for it, they came to him
coherently, though slowly.

6129.text:
"How was this?—_Was it you_?"
Once more, the two spectators started, as

6139.text:
he turned upon her with a frightful suddenness.
But she sat perfectly still in his grasp,

6145.text:
and only said, in a low voice, "I entreat
you, good gentlemen, do not come near us,

6150.text:
do not speak, do not move!"
"Hark!" he exclaimed. "Whose voice was that?"

6157.text:
His hands released her as he uttered this
cry, and went up to his white hair, which

6162.text:
they tore in a frenzy. It died out, as everything
but his shoemaking did die out of him, and

6169.text:
he refolded his little packet and tried to
secure it in his breast; but he still looked

6174.text:
at her, and gloomily shook his head.
"No, no, no; you are too young, too blooming.

6183.text:
It can't be. See what the prisoner is. These
are not the hands she knew, this is not the

6189.text:
face she knew, this is not a voice she ever
heard. No, no. She was—and He was—before

6195.text:
the slow years of the North Tower—ages ago.
What is your name, my gentle angel?"

6202.text:
Hailing his softened tone and manner, his
daughter fell upon her knees before him, with

6209.text:
her appealing hands upon his breast.
"O, sir, at another time you shall know my

6216.text:
name, and who my mother was, and who my father,
and how I never knew their hard, hard history.

6222.text:
But I cannot tell you at this time, and I
cannot tell you here. All that I may tell

6228.text:
you, here and now, is, that I pray to you
to touch me and to bless me. Kiss me, kiss

6234.text:
me! O my dear, my dear!"
His cold white head mingled with her radiant

6241.text:
hair, which warmed and lighted it as though
it were the light of Freedom shining on him.

6247.text:
"If you hear in my voice—I don't know that
it is so, but I hope it is—if you hear in

6253.text:
my voice any resemblance to a voice that once
was sweet music in your ears, weep for it,

6260.text:
weep for it! If you touch, in touching my
hair, anything that recalls a beloved head

6265.text:
that lay on your breast when you were young
and free, weep for it, weep for it! If, when

6272.text:
I hint to you of a Home that is before us,
where I will be true to you with all my duty

6278.text:
and with all my faithful service, I bring
back the remembrance of a Home long desolate,

6284.text:
while your poor heart pined away, weep for
it, weep for it!"

6291.text:
She held him closer round the neck, and rocked
him on her breast like a child.

6297.text:
"If, when I tell you, dearest dear, that your
agony is over, and that I have come here to

6304.text:
take you from it, and that we go to England
to be at peace and at rest, I cause you to

6310.text:
think of your useful life laid waste, and
of our native France so wicked to you, weep

6315.text:
for it, weep for it! And if, when I shall
tell you of my name, and of my father who

6323.text:
is living, and of my mother who is dead, you
learn that I have to kneel to my honoured

6329.text:
father, and implore his pardon for having
never for his sake striven all day and lain

6335.text:
awake and wept all night, because the love
of my poor mother hid his torture from me,

6341.text:
weep for it, weep for it! Weep for her, then,
and for me! Good gentlemen, thank God! I feel

6350.text:
his sacred tears upon my face, and his sobs
strike against my heart. O, see! Thank God

6359.text:
for us, thank God!"
He had sunk in her arms, and his face dropped

6365.text:
on her breast: a sight so touching, yet so
terrible in the tremendous wrong and suffering

6372.text:
which had gone before it, that the two beholders
covered their faces.

6377.text:
When the quiet of the garret had been long
undisturbed, and his heaving breast and shaken

6383.text:
form had long yielded to the calm that must
follow all storms—emblem to humanity, of

6390.text:
the rest and silence into which the storm
called Life must hush at last—they came

6396.text:
forward to raise the father and daughter from
the ground. He had gradually dropped to the

6402.text:
floor, and lay there in a lethargy, worn out.
She had nestled down with him, that his head

6408.text:
might lie upon her arm; and her hair drooping
over him curtained him from the light.

6415.text:
"If, without disturbing him," she said, raising

Tellson's Bank by Temple Bar was an old-fashioned

6896.text:
place, even in the year one thousand seven
hundred and eighty. It was very small, very

6902.text:
dark, very ugly, very incommodious. It was
an old-fashioned place, moreover, in the moral

6908.text:
attribute that the partners in the House were
proud of its smallness, proud of its darkness,

6915.text:
proud of its ugliness, proud of its incommodiousness.
They were even boastful of its eminence in

6921.text:
those particulars, and were fired by an express
conviction that, if it were less objectionable,

6929.text:
it would be less respectable. This was no
passive belief, but an active weapon which

6934.text:
they flashed at more convenient places of
business. Tellson's (they said) wanted no

6941.text:
elbow-room, Tellson's wanted no light, Tellson's
wanted no embellishment. Noakes and Co.'s

6948.text:
might, or Snooks Brothers' might; but Tellson's,
thank Heaven—!

6953.text:
Any one of these partners would have disinherited
his son on the question of rebuilding Tellson's.

6959.text:
In this respect the House was much on a par
with the Country; which did very often disinherit

6965.text:
its sons for suggesting improvements in laws
and customs that had long been highly objectionable,

6971.text:
but were only the more respectable.
Thus it had come to pass, that Tellson's was

6978.text:
the triumphant perfection of inconvenience.
After bursting open a door of idiotic obstinacy

6986.text:
with a weak rattle in its throat, you fell
into Tellson's down two steps, and came to

6992.text:
your senses in a miserable little shop, with
two little counters, where the oldest of men

6998.text:

7005.text:

7011.text:

7017.text:

"the House," you were put into a species of

7025.text:
Condemned Hold at the back, where you meditated
on a misspent life, until the House came with

7032.text:

blink at it in the dismal twilight. Your money

7039.text:

drawers, particles of which flew up your nose

7047.text:
and down your throat when they were opened
and shut. Your bank-notes had a musty odour,

7055.text:
as if they were fast decomposing into rags

7061.text:

7068.text:

7075.text:

7082.text:

that always had a great dining-table in it

7088.text:
and never had a dinner, and where, even in
the year one thousand seven hundred and eighty,

7094.text:
the first letters written to you by your old
love, or by your little children, were but

7100.text:
newly released from the horror of being ogled

7105.text:
on Temple Bar with an insensate brutality

7114.text:
But indeed, at that time, putting to death

7119.text:

7125.text:

the forger was put to Death; the utterer of

7132.text:

7139.text:

7144.text:

7151.text:
the sounders of three-fourths of the notes

Not that it did the least good in the way

7167.text:

and left nothing else connected with it to

7172.text:
be looked after. Thus, Tellson's, in its day,
like greater places of business, its contemporaries,

7180.text:

7186.text:

7191.text:
light the ground floor had, in a rather significant

7203.text:
on the business gravely. When they took a

7244.text:

7251.text:

7257.text:

7264.text:

7293.text:

apparently under the impression that the Christian

7323.text:

7355.text:

7394.text:

7400.text:
